intro: Amygdalopsis lindleyi, commonly known as the desert almond, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Rosaceae family and is characterized by its small, showy pink or white flowers that bloom in spring. The plant has a woody stem and produces small, almond-like fruits that contain a single seed. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and often have a hairy texture, adapted to reduce water loss in dry environments. Amygdalopsis lindleyi is well-suited to xerophytic conditions and is often found in rocky soils and desert scrub habitats.
